Fig. 1 Histograms of the particle size distribution of the different catalysts. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the as-synthesized catalysts (top), magnification of the XRD patterns from 36 to 48° (left bottom) and magnification of the XRD patterns from 62 to 72° (right bottom). Fig. 3 Percentages of the area of the Pd0 and PdCx versus wt.% Pd, as deduced from the Rietveld refinement of the XRD data. Fig. 4 Pd 3d core level spectra of the different catalysts (only Pd 3d5/2 components of the different Pd species were drawn in distinct colors). Fig. 5 Pd/C atomic ratio for each Pd species detected by XPS vs. the wt.% of Pd obtained by ICP-OES. Fig. 6 Reaction rates of two different representative catalysts (5Pd/C and 10Pd/C) determined at different reaction times as to have very low conversion and yields. Graphical abstract A series of carbon-supported palladium catalysts (Pd/C) with average particle size in the range from 3 to 7 nm was prepared by varying the Pd loading. These materials and the influence of their physicochemical properties in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of maleic acid (MAc) to succinic acid (SAc) using formic acid (FAc) as H2 donor were evaluated. The chemical, textural, and surface properties were studied by a number of characterization techniques (ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, and XPS). It was found that the intrinsic rate of SAc formation per surface Pd atom (turn-over frequency, TOF Pdsur) is structure-sensitive. The TOF Pdsur rate increases with the particle size following a volcano-type curve, reaching a maximum for an average particle size of ca. 6 nm. Assuming a cuboctahedral shape with a cubic close-packed structure, an approximation frequently adopted for Pd particles, it was found that, for the series of catalysts, neither the calculated TOF of Pd surface atoms at low coordination sites nor at high coordination are constant. This suggests that no geometric effect is responsible for the structure-sensitivity. Among the different Pd species present in the catalysts (i.e., metallic Pd (Pd0), palladium carbide (PdCx), and oxidized Pd), it was observed that the relative number of surface Pd0 sites also follows a volcano-type curve, which indicates that Pd0 sites are necessarily involved in the most active centers. For particles with an average size larger than 4 nm, the TOF rate of surface Pd0 sites was constant and in the range of 0.12 s−1. For smaller sizes, a more accurate determination of their Pd0 surface concentration is required to obtain reliable surface Pd0 TOF rates. Keywords Pd/C Maleic acid Succinic acid Formic acid Catalytic transfer hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Succinic acid (SAc) and its dehydrated anhydride form succinic anhydride find a wide variety of industrial applications as food additives, chemicals, solvents, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and in the production of biodegradable polymers such as poly(butylene succinate) [1–3]. SAc production largely relies on a petrochemical route that requires the oxidation of hydrocarbons (benzene and mainly butane) to maleic anhydride, which is then hydrogenated to the succinic anhydride or to its acid form [4,5]. A renewable route based on the fermentation of sugars has emerged driven by sustainability, public, and environmental concerns [6–9]. Although several demonstration plants have been opened to validate the feasibility of this route, the market price of the SAc produced by the fermentative route is still above the petrochemical SAc, burdened by the access to cheap feedstock and the setbacks associated with the separation and purification from the broth. The petrochemical route to succinic acid can be converted into a fully renewable pathway if starting from biomass derived maleic anhydride (or its acid form) and using green H2 for its hydrogenation. Interestingly, several routes to obtain maleic anhydride or maleic acid (MAc) from biomass have been technically demonstrated [3,10,11]. Besides, biomass-derived formic acid can supply the H2 needed for hydrogenation [12,13]. Furthermore, within this context, the simultaneous decomposition of formic acid (FAc) to provide the H2 needed for the hydrogenation of MAc to SAc can be concurrently conducted in the same catalytic bed by the so-called catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) reaction using Pd catalysts. Previous studies conducted by our group demonstrated that above 98 % yield of SAc can be obtained using Pd/C catalysts in aqueous solutions (no need of organic solvents), using a stoichiometric FAc/MAc ratio (no excess of FAc is required) and that the Pd/C system, although undergoing mild deactivation, is very robust and productive [14,15]. The characterization studies of the Pd/C system also led us to conclude that three different Pd species coexist in the catalyst, namely metallic Pd (Pd0), Pd carbide phases (PdCx), and oxidized Pd [14,15]. Beyond this practical information, no fundamental studies have been invested in revealing the most relevant Pd species for the reaction (if any) (electronic effects) or if Pd/C catalysts are sensitive to geometric effects, that is, if low coordination sites (corners, edges, steps, and kinks) or high coordination sites (facets) at the surface of the Pd particle show distinctive reactivity. Several studies have addressed this issue for one of the reactions involved in our system; i.e., the decomposition of FAc to H2 and CO2 [16–18]. However, contradictory results have been obtained when correlating either electronic or geometric effects with the catalytic behavior in the FAc decomposition reaction. Yamashita et al. claimed that high coordination sites located at the terraces of the Pd particles are those mainly involved in the activity, irrespective of their chemical speciation [16]. In contrast, Lu et al. found that oxidized Pd species are the most active sites [17]. Partially in contradiction with this latter result, Xing et al. sustained that the most active site involves Pd0, but in the interphase between Pd0 and Pd oxide domains [18]. In addition to this, it is important to note that the FAc decomposition reaction is one of the two steps simultaneously involved in the overall CTH reaction because both the decomposition of FAc and the hydrogenation of MAc take place concurrently. Therefore, an investigation is needed to reveal the sensitivity to the structure and whether sensitivity is governed by electronic or geometric effects in the reaction of CTH of MAc to SAc using FAc as the H2 source. To undertake this, a series of Pd/C catalysts with different particle sizes has been prepared by increasing the Pd loading while maintaining unchanged both the Pd precursor and the thermal protocol utilized to decompose it. This approach was selected to rule out the interferences of using different Pd precursors or different thermal activation protocols on the reactivity of Pd catalysts. The catalysts were characterized by a variety of techniques (ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, and XPS) to reveal the chemical, textural, and surface properties of the catalysts, particularly the presence and concentration of different Pd species and the particle size distribution. The intention of this investigation was not to identify the optimum Pd loading but to find activity-structure relationships. Initially, the Pd concentration was restricted to loadings below 10 wt%, but in the course of the investigation, it had to be expanded to much higher Pd loadings that, although unrealistic and uneconomical for practical applications, allowed a broader view of the reaction rate dependency on the particle size. Besides, using Pd loading above 5 wt% also results in high signal-to-noise ratio information from the characterization techniques and, consequently, in clearer identification of the Pd species that can be present in the catalysts. This provides solid foundations when extrapolating the information to the samples with lower Pd loading. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Maleic acid (99 wt%), formic acid (98 wt%), malic acid (99 wt%), fumaric acid (99 wt%), levulinic acid (99 wt%), 1,2-dichloromethane (anhydrous, 99.8 wt%), Pd (II) acetate (trace metal basis > 99.9 wt%), HNO3 (35 wt%), and NaOH aqueous solutions (50 wt%) were all supplied by Sigma Aldrich. Vulcan XC-72R supplied by Cabot Corporation was used as the carbon black support. 2.2 Preparation of carbon-supported Pd catalysts (Pd/C) Different Pd/C catalysts with different wt.% of nominal Pd (referred to the carbon support) were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation using Pd acetate dissolved in 1,2-dichloromethane (DCM) solutions. Before proceeding with the impregnation, the Vulcan XC-72R support was previously pretreated with 5 M HNO3 (10 mL solution/g support) at 383 K under reflux for 3 h. The treated support was filtered and washed thoroughly with water until neutral pH and dried at 383 K overnight. The volume of DCM needed for the incipient wetness impregnation (incipient volume) was determined experimentally by adding the required amount of DCM to a given weight of the support until incipient wetness. For the impregnation of the Pd precursor, the amount of Pd acetate needed to have 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, and 40 wt% of Pd referred to the carbon support was dissolved in the required volume of DCM. Droplets of the Pd acetate solution were slowly incorporated into a petri dish containing the HNO3-treated carbon and stirred with a glass bar to ensure the uniform spread of the solution over the whole support. Once all the Pd solution was added, the solid was dried overnight at 333 K in an oven. These catalyst precursors were first subjected to a thermal treatment at 573 K (5 K/min ramp) under 50 mL/min of N2 for 3 h to decompose the Pd acetate and to a H2-reduction treatment (50 mL/min) at 343 K (5 K/min ramp) for 1 h to ensure the complete reduction of Pd. Once at room temperature, the reduced catalyst was passivated with 100 mL/min of 3 v/v.% of O2/Ar for 2 h. The samples were labeled as XPd/C, where X represents the wt.% Pd incorporated into the impregnating solutions referred to the C support. Thus, 5Pd/C means the catalyst was prepared using a solution containing 5 wt% of Pd relative to the C support. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The Pd content of the fresh catalysts was determined by ICP-OES at Galbraith Laboratories, Inc., using a sodium peroxide fusion protocol. In summary, samples were fussed with sodium peroxide over a Bunsen burner and, subsequently, digested in acid at low temperature. The Pd dispersion and the mean particle size were calculated by measuring the particle size (diameter) of a number of representative collections of Pd particles (over 200) present in a set of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. The images were taken with a TEM/scanning TEM (STEM) (JEOL 2100F) microscope (200 kV with a field emission gun and point resolution of 0.19 nm). The mean dispersion was estimated from the relationship below, originally deduced by Borodziński et al. [19]: FE= 5.01 × d at × ∑ j n j d 2 + 2.64 × d at 0.81 × ∑ k n k d 2.19 ∑ i n i d i 3 where FE is the mean fraction of atoms exposed at the surface of the metal particles (dispersion), dat is the atomic diameter of Pd (0.274 nm), nj is the number of particles with a given diameter > 24dat, nk is the number of particles with a given diameter ≤ 24dat, and d is the diameter of the particles. From this FE, the Pd atoms present on the surface of the Pd particles per gram of catalyst can be calculated from the Pd loading experimentally obtained by chemical analysis. P d sur / g c a t = F E x w t . % o f P d a c t u a l l o a d i n g a t o m i c w e i g ht o f P d x 100 The mean particle size was calculated from the former FE value and according to the following equation [20]: diameter (nm) = 6 × V A 10 × FE where V is the volume occupied by a metal atom in the unit cell (14.6984 Å3 for Pd), and A is the area occupied by a Pd atom (7.9343 nm2). The average total number of Pd atoms in a particle of a given size within a cuboctahedron (NT) can be calculated using the following formula [21]: d = 1.105 × d at × N T 1 / 3 where d is the average diameter of the Pd particle size obtained from TEM analysis, and dat is the diameter of the Pd atom (0.274 nm). Alternatively, the Pd surface sites (NS), the high-coordination sites (NHS, only atoms on the facets of the cuboctahedron particle), and low-coordination sites (NLS, atoms on the edges and corners) can be estimated from the previous NT, once m is calculated (and assuming a cuboctahedron shape with a cubic close-packed structure, frequently used for Pd particles [21,22]): N T = 10 m 3 - 15 m 2 + 11 m - 3 / 3 N S = 10 m 2 - 20 m + 12 N HS = 6 m - 2 2 + 4 m - 3 m - 2 N LS = 24 m - 2 + 12 where m is the number of atoms lying on an equivalent edge [22,23]. From these values, the relative number of low coordination (NLS/Ns) and high coordination surface sites (NHS/Ns) with respect to the total number of surface Pd atoms can also be estimated. It is worth mentioning that the NS estimated with this approach is another mode of estimating the Pdsup value above calculated from TEM images. The quantity of irreversible CO chemisorbed over Pd particles was determined by the breakthrough curve methodology, employing a flow containing Ar, He and CO. Helium is used to trace the dead volume of the reactor and establish the zero-time point for the breakthrough curves. A more detailed description of the experiment can be found elsewhere [14] but in short the protocol is as follows. A mass spectrometer is connected to a U-shaped reactor that contains the sample (50 mg). In the first experiment and after the passivated catalysts have been re-reduced at 343 K, the H2 was fully removed from the lines by flowing only a Ar flow for 1 h. Subsequently, the flow was switched from Ar alone to a CO-He-Ar mixture. The CO breakthrough curve is delayed because of the irreversible and reversible CO chemisorption. Once the CO trace is stabilized (in practice more than 30 min) the flow switches back to only Ar and after 1 h, once no CO signal is detected, a second CO chemisorption cycle was conducted by flowing again CO-He-Ar. This second CO breakthrough curve is delayed only because of the reversible CO chemisorption. The irreversible CO chemisorbed on the Pd particles is determined by the difference between these two breakthrough curves. The number of Pd atoms at the surface of the Pd particles (Pdsur) was then calculated based on the assumption of a stoichiometry of CO/Pdsur = 2. X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD diffractometer working in reflection geometry (θ/2θ) and using the X'Celerator RTMS (Real Time Multiple Strip) detector with an active length of 2.122°. The patterns were collected with a long fine focus Cu tube working at 45 kV and 40 mA. The incident beam optic path contained a primary monochromator that yielded a strictly monochromatic, λ = 1.54059 Å radiation. A typical scan range was used, measuring from 4.0 to 90.0° (2θ) with a step size of 0.0167° and a scan step time of ca. 500 s. For the refinement of the crystal structure, the Rietveld method and the Fullprof crystallographic program were used. The function selected to generate the diffraction peak shape was a pseudo-Voigt. The parameters refined in the final run were the scale factor, linear interpolation between a set of background points, zero-point error, pseudo-Voigt parameters, cell parameters and isotropic thermal factors [24,25]. XPS spectra were recorded with a Physical Electronics PHI VersaProbe II spectrometer equipped with nonmonochromatic Al Kα radiation (53.6 W and 1486.6 eV) and a multichannel detector and using a 200-μm diameter analysis area. A PHI ACCESS ESCA-V6.0F software was utilized for the acquisition, and the CasaXPS program was used for the fitting and deconvolution of the different XPS spectra. Asymmetric line profiles were used to fit the shape of the XPS core levels and to determine the binding energies and the area of the different element core levels. A Shirley-type background was used to simulate the XPS background curve. CO-TPD experiments were conducted by loading the samples (ca. 50 mg) in a U-shaped quartz reactor heated by an electric furnace. The exit of the reactor was connected to a Balzer PrismaTM quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS 200) and the gas lines from the reactor outlet to the mass spectrometer inlet were heated to 393 K to prevent the condensation of H2O. The analysis was conducted as follows. First, the catalyst was subjected to a pretreatment with 50 mL·min−1 of wet Ar at 423 K (heating rate 0.083 K·s−1) for 1 h (wet Ar was obtained by bubbling at room temperature the Ar flow through liquid water contained in a flask) and then the sample was cooled down to 303 K while flowing wet Ar. To conduct the CO chemisorption, the flow was switched to 50 mL·min−1 of dry 10 % v/v CO/He and the sample allow to contact this stream for 30 min at 303 K. Then the sample was again contacted with 50 mL·min−1 of wet Ar for 2 h before conducting the so-called TPD-H2O-CO experiment in wet Ar by heating at 0.083 K·s−1 up to 800 K. The release of the following molecules was monitored by tracing the corresponding fragments: H2O (m/z = 18 and 17), CO (m/z = 28) and CO2 (m/z = 44 and 28). The intensity of the Ar fragment (m/z = 40) was used as an internal standard. Two blank experiments were also conducted: a first one called TPD-CO in which the step with wet Ar pretreatment at 423 K prior to the CO chemisorption was not conducted and a second one called TPD in which the sample was directly subjected to the heating without previous wet Ar or CO chemisorption steps. 2.4 Catalytic activity The required amounts of passivated catalyst, maleic acid, water, and formic acid were loaded into the batch reactor (Ace glass reactors, 15 mL), totaling 5 g of reaction mixture. The reactor was then immersed in a silicone bath set at the selected temperature (t0 of the experiment) and stirred at 1000 rpm with a magnetic bar for a given reaction time. To stop the reaction, the reactor was taken out from the silicone bath and let it cool down to room temperature. The reactor was depressurized, and a known amount (around 0.5 g) of an aqueous levulinic acid (LAc) solution (around 0.15–0.20 g of LAc /g of solution) was incorporated into the reaction mixture as an internal standard. This solution was filtered through a 0.22 μm syringe filter and analyzed in an Agilent 1200 HPLC chromatograph equipped with a refraction index detector and a Bio-Rad Aminex HPX-87H column (300 mm x 7.8 mm). A 0.005 M H2SO4 mobile phase was employed at 353 K and a 0.6 mL/min flow rate. MAc conversion and product yields were calculated according to the following formulas: M A c c o n v e r s i o n m o l % = m 0 MAc - m MAc m 0 MAc x 100 P r o d u c t y i e l d m o l % = m prod m 0 MAc x 100 where m0 MAc refers to the mole quantities initially loaded into the reactor, and mMAc, mFAc, mSAc, and mprod refer to the number of moles of MAc, SAc, and, in general, of any product of the reaction, respectively, in the mixture after reaction. The HPLC chromatographic factor of the organic products was calculated by analyzing solutions with known concentrations of the different organic products. The absence of external and internal mass transfer issues was evaluated and confirmed by applying the Mears and the Weisz-Prater criterion, respectively (see tables S1 and S2 in the supplementary information and the discussion therein). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results Table 1 collects the actual Pd loading determined by chemical analysis of the different samples. The data presented in Table 1 are not defined by the label of the sample (the wt.% Pd incorporated in the impregnating solution with respect to support) but by the actual wt.% Pd present in the sample. The values in brackets represent the nominal wt.% Pd calculated from the Pd incorporated into the impregnating solution. The actual values are quite similar to the nominal ones indicating that the preparation succeeded in incorporating most of the Pd initially used in the impregnating solution. Table 1 also includes the Pd dispersion and the average Pd. particle size deduced both from the TEM images and CO chemisorption. It must be stressed that equation of Borodziński was deduced based on the finding of a universal relation between FE and the diameter of any metal particle, irrespective of the shape of particle and the theoretical models used to calculate FE. The FE obtained by the equation of Borodziński is not based on an average particle size but is directly derived from the TEM-histograms and it can be compared to the dispersion values obtained from CO chemisorption. Fig. 1 shows the histogram of the particle size for the different catalysts, as obtained from the TEM images. As expected, the 0.5Pd/C sample is that with the highest dispersion (ca. 38 %) and the smallest average particle size (3.3 nm). The size of the Pd particles present in this specific catalyst is between 2 and 6 nm. Upon increasing the Pd loading, the Pd dispersion decreases and the average particle size increases, reaching the lowest dispersion (17.5 %) and the largest average particle size (6.4 nm) for the 40Pd/C catalyst. Fig. 1 also reveals the formation of larger particles when increasing the Pd loading, although particles smaller than 5 nm still persist. This indicates the presence of two distinct environments on the carbon surface, one that facilitates better Pd dispersion and another with inferior dispersing properties. For Pd loadings below 1–2 wt%, the smallest particles are formed in environments with the highest capacity to disperse Pd particles, resulting in sizes below 5–6 nm. As the Pd loading increases, these favorable sites become occupied, and other surface environments with poorer dispersing properties start to be filled, giving rise to particles larger than 6 nm and an increase of the average particle size determined from the TEM histograms. Table 1 also collects the Pd dispersion obtained by CO chemisorption and the diameter of the Pd particles calculated from it. These values are significantly different from those obtained from TEM images, with the dispersion being considerably larger and, consequently, the derived average particle size being smaller. The latter, between 2–3 nm, are not compatible with the distribution of particle diameters observed in the histograms of Fig. 1, that in some cases span even to beyond 10 nm large. Moreover, a discontinuity is observed in the trend of the average particle size for the catalysts with larger Pd loading (5Pd/C catalyst and beyond) and that of 2Pd/C and 1Pd/C samples (see Figure SI-1). Apparently, the CO chemisorption data are overestimating the dispersion (and underestimating the particle size). To match the CO chemisorption and TEM data, the stoichiometry of Pd/CO adsorption must be smaller than 1, rather than the widely accepted value of 2 for Pd catalysts. This indicates that the surface of Pd is not predominantly composed of metal Pd atoms, suggesting the presence of other Pd species or C contaminations at the surface of the Pd particles. As it will be shown below, Pd carbides are present in the Pd particles what can affect the properties or the stoichiometry of the CO chemisorption. Fig. 2 represents the XRD patterns of the catalysts (top figure), showing reflections associated with three different crystalline phases: carbon (circles), metallic Pd (triangles), and Pd carbide (stars). Pd carbide is represented as PdCx due to the difficulty in estimating the exact stoichiometry of the carbide phases. Figures at the left and right bottom positions magnify the regions between 2θ = 36-48° and 62-72°. Pd and PdCx phases both present a cubic structure with Fm-3 m space group. Their cell parameters are quite similar, however, in the case of PdCx, C atoms are located within the Pd atoms in the crystal structure, expanding the original Pd crystal lattice, and therefore enlarging the cell parameters. Consequently, the PdCx reflections appear very close to the ones of metallic Pd but shifted towards lower diffraction angles. In Figure displaying the 62–72 2θ region, the (220) reflections from Pd and PdCx can be more distinctly separated because the shift is more pronounced at higher 2θ and no carbon peak is present in this region. Carbon reflections dominate the patterns of the catalysts with lower Pd loadings (up to 10Pd/C); however, the Pd and PdCx reflections become dominant the for 20Pd/C and 40Pd/C samples. The presence of Pd carbides is not necessarily related to the carbon support because Pd carbides have also been reported on several non-C supported and non-supported Pd systems subjected to treatments with a variety of oxygenated and nonoxygenated organic molecules at moderate temperatures, even in the presence of O2 [26–31]. We have also reported that PdCx phases are formed at the expense of metal Pd and PdO when a Pd/C catalyst is used in the formic acid-driven CTH reaction of MAc to SAc [15]. The diffractograms of the samples with low Pd loadings have also been magnified so that the Pd and PdCx reflections in those samples can also be seen. Very incipient reflections from metallic Pd can be observed in the 0.5Pd/C sample (8 times magnification). The Pd (111), (200), and (220) (triangles) reflections from metallic Pd phase, located at around 2θ = 40.2, 46.8 and 68 °C, respectively, are more evident for the 1Pd/C catalyst. The presence of PdCx in these two former samples cannot be ruled out because the PdCx phase can be a minor phase, be amorphous or has a very small crystal size. On the contrary, the PdCx (111), (200), and (220) reflections (stars), located at smaller diffraction angles than those of metallic Pd, dominate in the 2Pd/C and 5Pd/C samples, indicating that higher Pd loadings preferentially form Pd carbide. However, on samples with even higher loadings, the metallic Pd reflections present intensities comparable to those of PdCx, and as a matter of fact, the Pd reflections in 40Pd/C are the most intense ones. The results from the Rietveld refinement of XRD data are summarized in Table 2 (Figure SI-2 shows the refinement of the structure of all samples analyzed). The Table also includes the wt.% of metallic Pd and Pd carbide in the samples. It was assumed that the Pd carbide phase was that with x = 1. Although other composition is possible, the wt.% would be also quite similar to the tabulated one because the atomic weight of Pd (106.4 g·mol−1) is almost one order of magnitude larger than that of carbon (12 g·mol−1). The refinement could not be accurately conducted in the 0.5Pd/C sample because of the low content of Pd. The Rietveld refinement of the 1Pd/C sample was satisfactorily fitted with the presence of only Pd reflections. As explained above, the presence of PdCx phase in both 0.5Pd/C and 1Pd/C catalysts cannot be ruled out because the lack of reflections from PdCx is likely due to the very small amount of PdCx, its amorphous character or the very small crystal size of PdCx. For the rest of the samples, the two phases coexist. Fig. 3 represents the wt.% of the contribution of Pd and PdCx deduced from the Rietveld refinement (0.5Pd/C phase is not represented). Reading from right to left, which is from the 40Pd/C sample (24 wt% Pd) to 2Pd/C sample (1.77 wt% Pd), it can be observed that as Pd loading decreases, the relative metallic Pd contribution also diminishes from a value close to 59 to 19 %. The PdCx phase shows the opposite trend, with increasing contribution as the Pd loading decreases, going from 41 % for the 40Pd/C system to 81 % for the 2Pd/C sample. For the 1Pd/C sample (0.95 wt% Pd), these trends are broken because that sample only exhibited metallic Pd reflections (100 % Pd and 0 % PdCx). As previously stated, the 0.5Pd/C sample (0.54 wt% Pd) is not shown in the figure because the fitting was not accurate. Although the small amount, the amorphous character or the small crystallite size of the PdCx phase prevents its detection by XRD studies in these two catalysts (thus, breaking the trend in Fig. 3), it will be shown later that the XPS results confirmed the presence of the PdCx phase on the 0.5Pd/C and 1Pd/C catalysts. In any case, it can be concluded that for 2Pd/C and beyond, the samples in which both Pd and PdCx phases are detected, the presence of metallic Pd phase increases (and that of PdCx decreases) as the Pd loading increases. Fig. 4 presents the Pd 3d core level spectra for the different fresh catalysts, and Table 3 summarizes the relevant information deduced from XPS (Table SI-3 includes also the FWMH of the peaks). The 5Pd/C signal was two-fold magnified, whereas that of 0.5Pd/C, 1Pd/C, and 2 Pd/C samples was 6 times magnified so that their represented signals have a comparable intensity to those of the more concentrated samples. The deconvolution used a Shirley background, a separation of 5.3 eV between the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 levels, and an area ratio of 3/2 between the spin–orbit components. An asymmetric line shape was adopted for Pd0 and PdCx species and Gaussian-Lorentzian for the rest of the Pd states. The Binding Energy (BE) of the same Pd species were restricted to variations of less of 0.1 eV and those of their FWMH to less than 0.4 eV around the selected value. The overall core level was deconvoluted by assuming the following peaks (regarding to Pd3d5/2 components): 335.5–335.6 eV assigned to Pd0 (green line in the figure), 336.0––336.1 eV assigned to Pd carbides (PdCx) (blue line in the figure), and 337.5 eV assigned to Pd2+ (orange line in the figure). A final fourth contribution at 338.5–338.6 eV (red wine line in the figure) has already been described in other oxidized Pd systems and assigned to Pd(IV) oxide stabilized on Pd2+ oxide [32–36], although it has also been assigned to the presence of highly dispersed and deficiently coordinated Pd2+ species [36]. In Table 3, they have been included as Pd(IV) species, but irrespective of the exact nature of this Pd species, this feature is evidence of the presence of, at least, two different oxidized Pd species in our Pd/C system, being the signal at 337.5 eV attributed to Pd2+ and that at 338.5–338.6 eV inconclusively assigned. It is worth remembering that the samples have been passivated in a 3 %O2/Ar flow after reduction, therefore the presence of Pd oxides over the surface of the particles is not unexpected. Weaker contributions, located at 2.6 and 8.6 eV from the main Pd2+ peak and representing 15 % and 5 % of the intensity of the Pd2+ components, were also included in the deconvolution, attributed to the satellites S1 and S2 (according to the nomenclature of Boronin et al. [37]). Although used in the deconvolution, they were not included either in Table 3 or Fig. 4 because of their low intensity for the sake of simplicity. Finally, a weak contribution at a very high BE (347.0 ± 0.3 eV) was assigned to the Pd0 plasmon contribution [37], neither included in the Table 3 and hardly visible in the Fig. 4. The XPS results confirm the previous XRD findings regarding the presence of both Pd0 and PdCx in the catalysts. The combined presence of these two species represents between 52–79 % of the Pd 3d core level area, indicating that they account for most of the Pd atoms, especially in the 5Pd/C sample and above. The two oxidized species are also visible and represent a non-negligible fraction of the overall Pd atoms. This is relevant because these Pd oxidized species are expected to be located over the surface of the Pd particles. The fourth column of Table 3 compares the atomic Pd/C atomic ratio deduced from XPS data (surface information) with that from the chemical analysis performed by ICP-OES (bulk composition, in brackets below the XPS value). The relative difference between these two values decreases as Pd loading increases, being the Pd/C XPS and bulk values quite similar in the 20Pd/C and 40Pd/C samples. This can be more easily observed in Figure SI-3, where the surface atomic Pd/C ratio by XPS is plotted against the bulk (ICP-OES). The dashed line represents those points in which the XPS surface ratio coincides with the bulk ones. It can be seen that almost all samples exhibit XPS-derived Pd/C atomic ratio values that are 2–3 times higher than the bulk values, except for the 20Pd/C and 40Pd/C catalysts, whose values are quite similar to the bulk ones. This is a consequence of the poorer dispersion of Pd on these latter samples. In Fig. 5 , the Pd/C atomic ratio for each Pd species detected by XPS is plotted against the Pd loading. These values indicate the relative concentration of each species in the different catalysts. Overall, the total Pd/C atomic ratio (XPS Pdt/C) increases with the Pd loading, but the increase rate is more significant in the catalysts with lower Pd loading and inferior for loadings higher than 8 wt% (sample 10Pd/C). This increase is not the same for all the species, and whereas the Pd(IV)/C, Pd2+/C, and PdCx/C atomic ratios experience a sustained increase with the Pd loading, the Pd0/C ratio exhibits a volcano-type curve, reaching a maximum for the 20Pd/C sample and smooth declining after this sample (40Pd/C sample). It is worth remembering that, unlike the previous bulk techniques, XPS is a technique that, similar to any catalytic process, is sensitive to the first layers of surface atoms. 3.2 Catalytic properties and reaction rates Scheme 1 summarizes the set of reactions taking place in the reaction medium. MAc can follow three possible pathways: the selective CTH hydrogenation to SAc, the isomerization of the double bond to the trans isomer fumaric acid (FumAc), and the hydration of the double bond to malic acid (MalAc). Besides, FumAc can also be hydrogenated to SAc, whereas MalAc cannot be transformed into SAc. The reaction proceeds via a concerted mechanism in which the formic acid transfers their H atoms to the double bond: the SAc formation rate is quite similar to the FAc conversion rate. It must be recalled that, under the conditions of low conversion used in these experiments, the formation of SAc from FumAc can be considered negligible. As we reported elsewhere [14], MAc severely inhibits the CTH reaction of FumAc to SAc. Only when MAc concentration is very low (in practice when conversion is above 80–90 %) FumAc is hydrogenated to SAc. Summarizing, the only route involved in the formation of SAc in the experiments here reported, at low MAc conversion, is the direct route from MAc. Fig. 6 collects the calculated reaction rates for two representative catalysts, 5Pd/C and 10Pd/C at different reaction times. Raw data are represented in Figure SI-4. The reaction conditions were selected to have very low yields of the different products (always below 10–15 %.). It is clearly observed that the reaction rates are similar within experimental error along the reaction times practiced in the experiments. Consequently, the variations in the concentration of reactants and products did not have any impact either in the reaction rates of the different products or in the calculated TOF values. Figure SI-5, representing the selectivity of the different products vs. the conversion of MAc, shows that the selectivities of all the products are constant in the low conversion range studied in Fig. 6 and SI-4. This means that under the conditions of low conversion used in these experiments, all the products are directly produced from MAc. This was expected for FumAc and MalAc but in the case of SAc these results suggest that the SAc formation from FumAc is negligible. As mentioned above and also reported elsewhere [14], MAc severely inhibits the CTH reaction of FumAc to SAc. Only when MAc concentration is very low (in practice when conversion is above 80–90 %) FumAc is hydrogenated to SAc. Summarizing, the only route involved in the formation of SAc in the experiments here reported, at low MAc conversion, is the direct route from MAc. Irreversible CO chemisorption has been pointed out as a source of deactivation of Pd/C catalysts when formic acid is dehydrogenated (to generate H2 and CO2) what may also affect the value of the reaction rate represented. It is well known that although the non-selective route (dehydration of formic acid to CO and H2O) takes place at very low extension, ppm concentration of CO can eventually chemisorbed on Pd sites, resulting in the deactivation by poisoning. CO-TPD experiments (see Fig. 7 ) were conducted on 5Pd/C and 10Pd/C catalysts subjecting the samples to a pretreatment with wet Ar prior to the CO chemisorption (see Experimental Section for details). These experiments were represented in the Fig. 7 as TPD-H2O-CO profiles. Two more blank experiments were conducted, a first one conducting the chemisorption of CO at room temperature but in the absence of wet Ar pretreatment (TPD-CO profiles) and a second one in which the fresh catalyst is subjected to the same temperature heating program of previous desorption experiments but without any CO or wet Ar pretreatment (TPD profiles). For both TPD-CO-H2O experiments, the release of CO at temperatures higher than 600 K is clearly observed. However, this CO release, more complex in the 10Pd/C sample than in the 5Pd/C sample, cannot be associated to the desorption of CO because it is also present in the blank TPD profiles without CO chemisorption (TPD profiles). This indicates that that CO release is not related to the chemisorption of CO but to the decarbonylation of the C support at temperatures higher than 600 K (CO2 desorption is not observed). No additional CO release peaks are observed in the TPD-H2O-CO experiments what means that chemisorption of CO has not taken place on either sample treated with wet Ar at 423 K. At this point, it is worth noticing that when the sample was not subjected to the pretreatment with wet Ar prior to CO chemisorption (TPD-CO profiles), clear CO desorption features are visible below 600 K for both catalysts, confirming that the treatment with H2O prevents the chemisorption of CO on the Pd sites. As expected these CO desorption peaks at low temperatures are neither observed when no CO is previously chemisorbed (blank TPD profiles). Concluding, the treatment of the catalysts with water at the reaction temperature (423 K) prevents the CO chemisorption. The prevention of CO poisoning when the catalysts are in contact with H2O at the reaction temperature may be derived from a competitive chemisorption of H2O over the Pd surface, that prevents the CO chemisorption. In practice, the deactivation of the catalyst by CO poisoning in the reactions conducted in Fig. 6 (and in Fig. 8 below) can be ruled out. To assess deactivation processes other than CO poisoning, the 5Pd/C and 10Pd/C catalysts were also reutilized under the same reaction conditions (results are shown in Figure SI-6). It is clearly observed that the catalysts do not suffer of deactivation and maintain the reaction rate in two successive runs. Consequently, it is concluded that the reaction rates measured under these reaction conditions are not affected by any process of deactivation. Fig. 8 represents the rate of consumption of MAc and formation of MalAc, FumAc, and SAc with the different catalysts. The reaction conditions were similar for all the catalysts (the same as in Fig. 6), except for the reaction time that was adjusted so that the yields of the different products were always below 15 %. The results shown in Fig. 8 are the average of at least three experiments with error bars for the different catalysts. The sum of the rates of formation of SAc, FumAc, and MalAc is quite similar to the rate of consumption of MAc; therefore, the carbon balance is close to 100 (± 5 %) in all cases. The MalAc formation rate is quite insensitive to the Pd loading, remaining at around 0.25–0.35 mmol of MalAc·gcat -1·min−1. On the contrary, the formation rates of both FumAc and SAc (being the latter the product of interest) are sensitive to the Pd loading. Both rates increase up to the 20Pd/C catalyst while the activity levels off beyond that. These results suggest that the rate of formation of SAc (and the isomerization to FumAc) could be sensitive to the Pd particle size, which will be thoroughly discussed below. It is worth stressing that the SAc formation rate is quite negligible with 0.5Pd/C, the catalyst with the lowest Pd loading, indicating that the carbon support is not involved in the CTH activity. On the other hand, Pd sites seem not to be involved in the MalAc formation because this is quite insensitive to the Pd loading. However, both carbon and Pd sites are involved in the isomerization of MAc to FumAc because the FumAc rate is not negligible at very low Pd loading. Moreover, FumAc follows a parallel behavior to SAc, as it grows with Pd loading and levels off for the 40Pd/C catalyst. The curve of the SAc formation rates presented in Fig. 8 shows a dependence on the Pd loading similar to the Pd0 quantity detected by XRD in Fig. 3 (excluding the 0.5Pd/C and 1 Pd/C catalysts): as the metallic Pd amount increases, the reaction rate increases up to the 20Pd/C sample, and then the 40Pd/C sample exhibits both an activity and a proportion of metallic Pd similar to that of 20Pd/C. This strongly suggests that metallic Pd may be involved in the most active sites in the CTH reaction from MAc to SAc (further evidence will be provided below). Fig. 9 exhibits the intrinsic reaction rate of the SAc formation per Pd atom exposed to the surface (TOF Pdsur) as a function of the average particle size determined by TEM. The amount of surface Pd sites was the fraction of Pd atoms exposed to the surface as experimentally deduced from the actual Pd loading and Pd particle size distribution obtained by TEM studies and using the formula of Borodziński et al. as mentioned in the Experimental section [19]. Fig. 9 does not include the TOF numbers for MalAc and FumAc because the surface sites from the C support are also involved in their formation; therefore, their TOF Pdsur numbers would be erroneously overestimated when divided by the amount of Pd surface atoms. It is clearly seen that the TOF Pdsur values for SAc grows with the Pd particle size up to the 20Pd/C catalyst (average particle size of 5.8 nm), and it decreases for larger particle sizes (6.4 nm for the 40Pd/C catalyst). In conclusion, the CTH of MAc to SAc with Pd/C systems is a reaction sensitive to the structure, showing a volcano-type dependence with the particle size with a maximum at 5.8 nm. Therefore, increasing the Pd loading up to ca. 20 wt% provides the largest amount of the most active Pd species. As explained in the Introduction section, contradictory explanations have been given to rationalize the dependence of the reaction rate of FAc decomposition to H2 and CO2 with the particle size. Even though the latter is just one of the two reactions involved in our more complex system, which simultaneously involves both the decomposition of FAc and the hydrogenation of MAc, these previous simpler studies constitute a guide for our more complex reaction. Yamashita et al. found that the formic acid decomposition reaction rate does not depend on the chemical nature of the Pd sites but on the concentration of high coordination sites located at the terraces of the Pd particles [16]. When they represented the TOF values of these high coordination sites in the different catalysts as a function of the particle size, they found that these TOF values were quite similar and that the trend was quite well described by a straight line with a negligible slope (a horizontal line). Conversely, other authors have found that the reaction is not explained by geometrical effects but by electronic effects. For example, Lu et al. did not find this horizontal straight line dependency between the TOF and neither high coordination nor low coordination sites. They identified that oxidized Pd species are the most active sites [17], whereas Xing et al. maintain that Pd0 in the interphase between Pd0 and Pd oxide domains are those with the highest activity [18]. In order to assess if geometric effects explain the sensitivity to the structure displayed in Fig. 9, the relative numbers of low and high coordination sites (HS and LS) present at the surface of the particles were estimated following the methodology described in the Experimental section. HS are the surface atoms located on the terraces of the facets of the particles, whereas LS are the atoms on edges and corners. This approach is commonly accepted for these types of studies and assumes that cuboctahedron particles with a cubic close-packed structure describe the Pd particles present over the Carbon surface. Table SI-4 summarizes the particle size and the values of m, NT, Ns/NT, NHS/Ns, and NLS/Ns for each of the catalysts in this study, based on the equations described elsewhere [21,22]. NT represents the total number of Pd atoms in the average particle size determined from TEM images, Ns/NT accounts for the dispersion as it is the ratio between the atoms at the surface of the particle and the total number of Pd atoms in the whole particle, and NHS/Ns and NLS/Ns represent the fraction of high coordination and low coordination sites, respectively, relative to the total number of surface sites (Ns). The TOF regarding HS and LS sites can then be calculated by dividing the overall TOF value of Pdsur by NHS/Ns and NLS/Ns, respectively. Fig. 10 compares the overall TOF Pdsur of SAc formation for the different catalysts with the TOF numbers for the HS and LS sites. For the sake of comparison, a logarithmic scale is used. If either of these HS or LS sites were responsible for the activity, their TOF numbers would be very similar for the different catalysts, and the representation of the trend as a function of particle size would be a horizontal straight line (or with a very small slope). As mentioned above, Yamashita et al. obtained a horizontal straight line in the decomposition reaction of formic acid [16]. However, that was not the case with the two trends represented in Fig. 10. TOF values for HS and LS sites have also been estimated using other particle shapes (icosahedron and rhombic dodecahedron) in cubic close-packed Pd particles and mathematical models for the determination of m, NT, Ns/NT, NHS/Ns, and NLS/Ns (Tables SI-5 and SI-6 and Figures SI-7 and SI-8). In none of these cases, the trend of TOF for HS or LS sites can be adjusted to a horizontal straight line. Consequently, it can be concluded that the sensitivity of the reaction rate to the particle size is not inherently related to the high or low coordination sites on the particle surface and the geometrical effects do not explain the dependence of the TOF Pdsur of SAc formation with the particle size. Hence, the chemical features of the Pd atoms must explain the volcano-type curve in Fig. 9. Although XRD data already suggested that Pd0 is the most active species, XPS results confirm that hypothesis as described below. Fig. 11 represents the TOF of surface Pd0 (the intrinsic reaction rate for surface Pd0 atoms determined by XPS) as a function of the particle size. To calculate the TOF of surface Pd0, the TOF of surface Pd (TOF Pdsur) must be divided by the relative amount of Pd0 at the surface with respect to the total amount of surface Pd atoms (Pd0/Pd)sur. It is assumed that the latter can be substituted by the atomic ratio obtained by XPS, (Pd0/Pd)XPS. The XPS signal arose from the uppermost atoms of the surface, and consequently, XPS is a technique sensitive to the surface composition. The (Pd0/Pd)XPS ratio is, in practice, obtained by dividing the (Pd0/C)XPS value by that of (Pdt/C)XPS represented for each catalyst in Fig. 5. Interestingly, Fig. 11 shows that, for particle size larger than 4 nm (1Pd/C sample and above), the TOF value for surface Pd0 is constant and, within the experimental error, around 0.12 s−1. In conclusion, this indicates that the reaction is sensitive to the chemical nature of the Pd species present at the surface (electronic effects) and not to specific location of the Pd atoms in the particle surface (geometric effects). We propose that Pd0 must be involved in the most active sites. This does not necessarily mean that Pd0 is the active sites. It is very reasonable to expect that the outermost layers of the Pd particles is dominated by the presence of Pd oxidized species and, in consequence, it should not be expected that Pd0 is exposed to the gas phase. However, the results here presented demonstrate that Pd0 species are necessarily involved in the most active sites. Regarding this, it is worth bringing out that Xing et al. claimed that for the reaction of decomposition of formic acid the interphase between Pd0 and Pd oxide domains [18] is where the most active sites are. The deviation to lower TOF of surface Pd0 for the 0.5Pd/C sample (average particle size of 3.3 nm) could be attributed to the fact that in this sample (along with the 1Pd/C and 2Pd/C samples), the Pd loading and, consequently, the XPS signal-to-noise ratios, are very low, resulting in an inaccurate (Pd0/Pd)XPS ratio. A more accurate determination of the relative surface Pd0 concentration for particles smaller than 4 nm would be required to confirm their lower TOF of surface Pd0. It may also be possible that for Pd particles with an average size below 4 nm, the surface Pd0 is not involved in the most active site, and other surface Pd sites may come into play. However, either of these two options would indicate that the reaction is sensitive to the speciation of Pd. Further research is needed to confirm whether, for particle sizes below 4 nm, Pd0 remains the species with the highest intrinsic activity or if there are other Pd sites responsible for the activity. The increase in the Pd0 proportion determined by XPS with the particle size is a trend that has already been observed in Pd/C catalysts used for the decomposition of formic acid to CO2 and H2 in the 2–4.5 nm particle size range [17]. However, in this previous study, the TOF per surface Pd center decreased with the particle size and did not show a volcano-type curve, which is contrary to our results. As previously mentioned, the CTH reaction is a more complex system involving two concurrent reactions, the formic acid decomposition and the MAc hydrogenation. In summary, it is proposed that, for the CTH reaction and this catalytic system, within the range of particles studied in the present work, the sensitivity of the TOF Pdsur for SAc formation to the particle size is determined by the ability to stabilize Pd0 on the surface of Pd particles. The relative surface quantity of Pd0 grows as the particle size increases, reaching a maximum for particles with an average size in the range of 6 nm. For larger particles, the fraction of Pd0 decreases, which explains the plateau of the overall rate of SAc formation reaction per gram of catalyst observed in Fig. 8. The questions that still remain are, first, why the surface amount of Pd0 increases up to an average particle size in the range between 4–6 nm and then slightly decreases for larger particles and, second, to confirm the continuity of this effect for particles below 4 nm. Two final comments about the involvement of the metallic Pd0 sites in the active sites and the determination of the number of HS and LS in the Pd particles present in the catalyst. It is not realistic that metallic Pd0 sites are the real active sites because those sites are not expected to be present at the outermost layer of the Pd particles. As commented above, the Pd particles are more likely to be covered by Pd oxide species (the catalysts are passivated after reduction). But the results here presented provide evidences of that Pd0 is required and involved in the active sites. A plausible explanation is that Pd oxide species (or layers of Pd oxide) on top of Pd0 domains rather than on PdCx are the most active site. This work has showed the complex nature of the Pd particles deposited over the C surface, a system that is frequently overlooked by the very simpler approach of assuming the presence of only Pd0 atoms and neglecting or missing (the presence of) PdCx and Pd oxides. More research is needed to clarify the hypothesis that Pd0 is involved in the active site, especially considering that the system can be even more complex than that described in this work. It must be borne in mind that the catalyst can be substantially modified because of a reaction taking place at 423 K and in the presence of water and reducing molecules like formic. The chemical features of the Pd particles can be modified because of the immersion in the reaction mixture. Regarding the determination of LS and HS in the metal Pd particles, the methodology adopted in this article is that frequently accepted and used in the bibliography [16–23], that has allowed to propose that either geometric or electronic effects explain the structure sensitivity in reactions catalyzed by metal particles (like the decomposition of formic acid, a reaction very related to our CTH reaction). This methodology is an approximation that estimates the fraction of LS or HS based on an average of Pd size calculated from the distribution of Pd particles observed in TEM images. Other more sophisticated approaches are needed to really determine the number of LS and HS, especially in wide distributions of Pd particles like those found in this manuscript. This is out of the goal of this article, that, in any case, has undeniably demonstrated that CTH of MAc to SAc is a reaction sensitive to the structure and that metallic Pd is involved somehow in the active sites. 4 Conclusions The catalytic transfer hydrogenation of MAc to SAc, using FAc as the hydrogen donor and Pd/C as the catalyst, is sensitive to the structure. This sensitivity of the rate of formation of SAc per surface Pd atom (TOF Pdsur) exhibits a maximum for an average particle size close to 6 nm, decreasing for larger particle sizes. Characterization data have revealed that the sensitivity to the structure is not due to geometric effects but rather to electronic effects. More specifically, it has been shown that Pd0 sites are necessarily involved in the most active centers, as both the TOF and the surface concentration of Pd0 follow the same trend regarding the average particle size. The intrinsic activity of surface Pd0 (TOF of surface Pd0) has been estimated to be around 0.12 s−1 for particle distributions with an average diameter greater than 4 nm. For smaller sizes, the TOF of surface Pd0 was found to be lower, suggesting that Pd0 may no longer be involved in the most active species. However, this hypothesis requires experimental confirmation through further investigations. CRediT authorship contribution statement A. coredata.dc:description: A series of carbon-supported palladium catalysts (Pd/C) with average particle size in the range from 3 to 7 nm was prepared by varying the Pd loading. These materials and the influence of their physicochemical properties in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of maleic acid (MAc) to succinic acid (SAc) using formic acid (FAc) as H2 donor were evaluated. The chemical, textural, and surface properties were studied by a number of characterization techniques (ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, and XPS). It was found that the intrinsic rate of SAc formation per surface Pd atom (turn-over frequency, TOF Pdsur) is structure-sensitive. The TOF Pdsur rate increases with the particle size following a volcano-type curve, reaching a maximum for an average particle size of ca. 6 nm. Assuming a cuboctahedral shape with a cubic close-packed structure, an approximation frequently adopted for Pd particles, it was found that, for the series of catalysts, neither the calculated TOF of Pd surface atoms at low coordination sites nor at high coordination are constant. This suggests that no geometric effect is responsible for the structure-sensitivity. Among the different Pd species present in the catalysts (i.e., metallic Pd (Pd0), palladium carbide (PdCx), and oxidized Pd), it was observed that the relative number of surface Pd0 sites also follows a volcano-type curve, which indicates that Pd0 sites are necessarily involved in the most active centers. For particles with an average size larger than 4 nm, the TOF rate of surface Pd0 sites was constant and in the range of 0.12 s−1. For smaller sizes, a more accurate determination of their Pd0 surface concentration is required to obtain reliable surface Pd0 TOF rates.
